name: The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing: Final Cut
description: Embark on an adventure in a gothic-noir world, where mad science threatens the peace between monsters and mortals. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing: Final Cut is definitive edition of the trilogy with six playable classes and a new endgame mode with a huge variety of open missions!

reviews.review_text: Final Cut combines the storyline and refines the gameplay mechanics of the previous trilogy games.  The gameplay mechanics is improved in all aspects:  1. The character classes are those from the third part of the trilogy, and namely Protector, Bounty Hunter, Elementalist, Umbralist, Phlogistoneer and Constructor;  2. The character attributes are now only 3 and are different for every class, and every attribute is important;  3. The skills are combination from the skills in the trilogy games and are now organized in tiers and branches:  3.1. There are 3 skill-tiers - the first one is accessible from the character creation, the second and the third are accessible at levels 20 and respectively 40;  3.2. The branches are 3 linked skills from each of the tiers, to learn skill from tier 2, you should have learned it's linked skill from tier 1, respectively to learn skill from tier 3, you should have learned it's linked skill from tier 2, and in addition there are synergy-bonuses between the linked skills from given branch, given skill from tier 2 receives synergy from it's linked skill from tier 1, respectively given skill from tier 3 receives synergy from it's linked skills from tier 2 and tier 1;  4. The character progression is now smoother and there is no inflation according to attributes and gear-bonuses;  5. There are now 2 major modes - offline and online:  5.1. In online mode your characters and shared chest is stored on Neocore-cloud and your characters get downloaded for every gaming-session, it requires internet-connectivity but DOESN'T require uninterrupted connection, in this major mode, in addition to the story and multiplayer, the players may experience the new end-game modes (Scenarios, Events and Daily Quests);  5.2. In offline mode your characters and shared chest are stored on your machine, just like it was in the trilogy games, in this major mode you can play story and multiplayer with friends, and the end-game content.  At the end my opinion for the game is that it's really what most of us wanted, it's improved in every aspect. Neocore deserve deep admiration for bringing us the game in this brilliant state. They have it from me!  I was one of the beta-testers of the game, and I am grateful to the devs that they gave me the chance to contribute somehow to this brilliant game!

The Final Cut allows you to replay the previous Van Helsing games with the new class/skill set up that was not present in the previous games, and also unlike the normal release of the third installment is not a bug ridden mess. This game series for me is probably one of my favorite, it makes me harken back to days (and nights, lots and lots of nights) wherein I played Diablo II for hours and hours not really accomplishing anything but throughly enjoying it. This combines that class loot and exp grind of ARPGs like Diablo II and presents it in a world that whilst presents itself as being very dark, knows full well what it is and makes light of almost every situation with really enjoyable comic dialogue between the two main characters.  Full of hidden secrets, loot, near infinite (unashamed hyperbole) character build paths, and at least 20 hours of enjoyable main storyline with great dialogue, this game is well worth its cost and I cannot recommend it enough to ARPG fans with a sense of humor. Though the game has it's fair share of faults, none of which I can objectively talk about with these rose colored glassess glued to my face, but it, like most indie games, has a fair number of clunk and lack of smoothness to it, but nothing really that ever got in the way of me enjoying myself. Overall rating: 9/10

So having played through the three games previously I thought I'd give my opinion of the Final Cut edition to help new users to the series to decide if it's worth it.  and I'd highly recommend it  and here's why:  Firstly it's a standard diablo-style hack'n'slash game, with thousands of enemies, lots of loots and a fairly linear path to go alone. Whilst this means it won't set new standards for the genre, they do the basics well. There are also tower-defence style missions to help break up the main game as well as multiplayer options and a scenario mode.  The setting and characters gives the game a fresh twist, instead of the usual dungeons and dragons theme, we have Van Helsing, the famous monster hunter. Whilst not a huge change it is something original and makes for a nice change,  This is also the first time in the series that you can have one character playthrough the entire three games which lets you get better connected to your character. You can also play as any of the six classes for the entire game as well, whereas previously they added classes as the series went on.  Getting the game's Final Cut edition also allows you to get the game after the previous ones have effectively been tested. The skill system has been re-worked to be the same throughout all the games, level cap has been raised and bugs and nuisences have been removed.  The game's store page says you'll get around 50 hours in total and this seems about right as my time in the three seperate games came to 56 hours; and even at it's full price it gives good value for money.  If you're a fan of hack'n'slash games then you'll enjoy this, it's easily worth the price and I found it to be quite a pleasant surprise when I played it.  If you are unsure then search the steam store page for 'Van Helsing' as there is a demo still available of the first game, whilst skills and classes may have changed since then, it can give you a good chance to test it before parting with your money.

I am new to the VH Series. Having just purchased the first TIAOVH during the Halloween Sale, i played around an hour and I fell in love with the story and the dialog between VH and Katrinia also the skill and leveling system of the game. After playing I purchased the franchise. At that time I was unaware of VH: Final Cut. I had just completed VH1 and was set to start VH2 when the Final Cut was released.   The final cut is worth playing, the leveling changed enough to make me feel like i was not playing the same game again. I also noticed quest changes and additions, which made it still feel fresh and fun. They took away 2 classes from VH1 and added 5 more.  I am sure there are more in-depth reviews you can find with all the changes/additions and so-on, however if you enjoy monsters and guns with a side of steam-punk...well this is the game for you.  On a side note: The original VH franchise is worth getting if you can grab it on a sale like they had for Halloween (VH1,2,3 and Deathtrap for $25). Playing through VH1, i already knew I wanted to give it a 2nd play through and VH: Final Cut is the best possible 2nd play through. Some thing old, yet new and exciting.

The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing - Final Cut is an action RPG that combines the three previous Van Helsing games into one unified campaign. Before this Final Cut version my exposure to the series was very limited as I had only briefly tried out the very first Adventures of Van Helsing game.  The game has all the features one would expect in a traditional action RPG. Unfortunately, the game suffers from bland gameplay and uneven production values. Graphics often feel dated, even with the optional high resolution texture pack. Some of the voice acting is also quite weak and other audio isn't particularly memorable, either.  The combat itself is pretty simplistic, most builds only use a few skills frequently. The monster design is fairly boring as well, so the game gets repetitive pretty fast. Luckily the bosses are a lot more varied and there are a few maps that break the monotony. Still, with no random maps the campaign has very little replay value.  The character development is not particularly deep or engaging either, there are not that many good builds per class and often the good choices are pretty obvious. On a positive note respecs are cheap so there's no big harm experimenting with builds. Itemization is not particularly interesting either as there only a very few truly unique items.  The game is quite story-driven, especially for an action RPG. The main story is decent enough and the game makes use of many different myths and stories. Side quests are more of a mixed bag. Some are interesting enough whereas others feel like filler content.  In addition to the your typical action RPG maps, the game has several different optional minigames that add a bit of variety to the campaign. None of these are particularly compelling, however. The tower defense minigame is by far the most involved of these. It's decent enough implementation of the basic tower defense formula, but it could have been integrated better into the game world. The other minigames provide very little actual gameplay, they are mainly there as opportunities to score some easy extra loot.  While I found my playthrough enjoyable enough, I'm finding it hard to recommend the game to anyone who is not already an action RPG fan. The core gameplay just isn't compelling enough and the game lacks replay value. However, if you can get the game cheap during a sale, it's compelling enough for a single playthrough.  I played through the game on hard with the Bounty Hunter class. After finishing the main game I also dabbled a bit with the scenario maps.  The good: - Interesting setting that mixes gothic and steampunk elements - Lady Katarina is a great sidekick and provides a lot of fun dialog - Lots of hidden secrets - Does a good job of combining three separate games into one fairly seamless whole - Lots of inventory and storage space  The bad: - Core gameplay is not very engaging - Character development and skill system appear deep on the surface, but on closer inspection the whole thing is a poorly balanced and not very interesting - Boring loot - Powering up skills with rage often feels clunky - Map design is often pretty bland - Voice acting ranges from passable to terrible - Overuse of pop culture references and jokes - Auto-leveling enemies that can lead to big difficulty spikes - Fairly dated graphics  The ugly: - Long loading times

There is no neutral rating for this game, and I stopped playing without finishing due to lack of fun, so I am giving it a negative rating.  I thought that the first two Van Helsing games were fun and played them all the way through. I liked that there was set gear to collect and that it was possible to load one's character from the first game into the second game. This game, like the third in the series, does not allow a player to load in an existing character. In addition, the set gear is no longer in the game until the very end and only if your character reaches the highest level possible (100).  The game as published currently is not well-balanced. My first new character was a Bounty Hunter and I was able to chew my way through to the third game with no problem. At that point I started to get bored so I made a constructor. I had fun with that character up until the bits in the second game when there are bombardments that fall on Borgova. The constructor relies on having a multitude of bot and turret constructs that do damage and protect him, and I found it next to impossible to avoid having my various constructs blown up by one to two bombardment hits. At this point I just decided it was pointless to continue as there are multiple times when your character is hit by bombardments in game and also in the adventure maps. I went looking for and found a new game to play.  If you have not played the first two Van Helsing games, then I recommend playing those as I found them to be more entertaining and the classes better constructed. If you played those already then I suggest waiting for a balance and/or update to this game (or using a mod if you really want to play it).  I really wanted to like this game more as I enjoy the setting, story, and steam punk atmosphere and critters. Oh well... so many other games to enjoy and so little time.
